title: China Auto Maker Geely Ventures Into Smartphones; Geely subsidiary has acquired a 79% stake in one of China's earliest but smallest smartphone makers, as Alibaba makes exit
text:
Founded almost 20 years ago as a manufacturer of MP3 players, Meizu was previously backed by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., which had a 27% stake in the company before Geely's entrance. Alibaba paid $590 million for stakes in the company in 2015 in an attempt to expand into the mobile market.

Despite being one of China's earliest smartphone makers and the backing from Alibaba, Meizu's share of the market has shrunk to almost zero as it was overshadowed by rivals such as Xiaomi Corp.

Following the acquisition, Geely's Hubei Xingji Shidai Technology Co. will gain sole control over Meizu, while Alibaba makes a complete exit. The shareholding of Meizu founder Huang Xiuzhang will shrink from 49.08% to 9.79%, according to the State Administration for Market Regulation, which first revealed the purchase in June.

Meizu will continue to operate as an independent brand following the acquisition while Xingji Technology strives to develop a "portfolio of next-generation smartphones, mobile devices and wearable smart devices that will utilize XR technologies," the companies' statement said.

Shen Ziyu, vice chairman of Xingji Technology, said buying Meizu will help the company dive into the consumer electronics market spanning gadgets to vehicle tie-ups.

The acquisition comes as other smartphone giants including Apple Inc. and Huawei Technologies Co. deepen their ventures into the market for smart electric vehicles.
